BREAKING: President Trump says on China's 145% tariff:
"I haven't brought it down, I said it's a high tariff, but I haven't brought it down."
Trump reiterates that if a deal is not made, tariffs will be set. (From TKL)

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 8) Times the monthly decline by 12 to get an annualized decline, to better understand the how much prices could drop over a year if current rates hold.
Data for nearly 30,000 ZIP codes is available at http://www.reventure.app. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
8) Times the monthly decline by 12 to get an annualized decline, to better understand the how much prices could drop over a year if current rates hold.

Data for nearly 30,000 ZIP codes is available at reventure.app.
item.contentSnippet: 8) Times the monthly decline by 12 to get an annualized decline, to better understand the how much prices could drop over a year if current rates hold. reventure.app.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 7) To access data on the housing markets with the biggest monthly price declines, create an account on Reventure App and sign up for a premium plan.
The Home Value Growth MoM data point is available under Home Prices & Affordability, and can be viewed down to the ZIP code level. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:

The Home Value Growth MoM data point is available under Home Prices & Affordability, and can be viewed down to the ZIP code level.

The Home Value Growth MoM data point is available under Home Prices & Affordability, and can be viewed down to the ZIP code level.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 6) Sellers on the housing market have seem to have "woken up", and are starting to give up their equity gains.
I anticipate this trend will continue over the rest of 2025 in Sun Belt and Mountain West housing markets, and potentially California. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
6) Sellers on the housing market have seem to have "woken up", and are starting to give up their equity gains.

I anticipate this trend will continue over the rest of 2025 in Sun Belt and Mountain West housing markets, and potentially California.
item.contentSnippet:
6) Sellers on the housing market have seem to have "woken up", and are starting to give up their equity gains.
I anticipate this trend will continue over the rest of 2025 in Sun Belt and Mountain West housing markets, and potentially California.

item.title: R to @nickgerli1: 5) Other markets where prices are dropping: Wichita, KS, Tampa, FL, Phoenix, AZ, and the aforementioned Colorado Springs. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content: 5) Other markets where prices are dropping: Wichita, KS, Tampa, FL, Phoenix, AZ, and the aforementioned Colorado Springs.
item.contentSnippet: 5) Other markets where prices are dropping: Wichita, KS, Tampa, FL, Phoenix, AZ, and the aforementioned Colorado Springs.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 4) Colorado is another interesting one. Denver actually has the highest housing inventory of any major metro in America, now ranking 90.9% above the long-term average.
There has been a huge supply explosion there, and in markets like CoSprings.
Which are starting to bring prices down. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
4) Colorado is another interesting one. Denver actually has the highest housing inventory of any major metro in America, now ranking 90.9% above the long-term average.

There has been a huge supply explosion there, and in markets like CoSprings.

Which are starting to bring prices down.
item.contentSnippet:
4) Colorado is another interesting one. Denver actually has the highest housing inventory of any major metro in America, now ranking 90.9% above the long-term average.
There has been a huge supply explosion there, and in markets like CoSprings.
Which are starting to bring prices down.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 3) Austin continues to drop. Values fell there -0.60% last month, are down -3.8% YoY, and are down over -20% from their peak in 2022.
Austin will soon be a legitimate buyers market if prices drop another 5-10%. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
3) Austin continues to drop. Values fell there -0.60% last month, are down -3.8% YoY, and are down over -20% from their peak in 2022.

Austin will soon be a legitimate buyers market if prices drop another 5-10%.
item.contentSnippet:
3) Austin continues to drop. Values fell there -0.60% last month, are down -3.8% YoY, and are down over -20% from their peak in 2022.
Austin will soon be a legitimate buyers market if prices drop another 5-10%.

item.title: R to @nickgerli1: 2) Other markets like Punta Gorda, Cape Coral, and North Port, Florida were expected. These markets were already down 6-7% over the last year, and they are continuing to drop. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content: 2) Other markets like Punta Gorda, Cape Coral, and North Port, Florida were expected. These markets were already down 6-7% over the last year, and they are continuing to drop.
item.contentSnippet: 2) Other markets like Punta Gorda, Cape Coral, and North Port, Florida were expected. These markets were already down 6-7% over the last year, and they are continuing to drop.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 1) For me the big surprise was seeing California markets now in the decliners list.
At Reventure, we started noticing the slowdown in California last month.
But we weren't expecting LA and San Jose to make the top 10 in terms of monthly declines. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
1) For me the big surprise was seeing California markets now in the decliners list.

At Reventure, we started noticing the slowdown in California last month.

But we weren't expecting LA and San Jose to make the top 10 in terms of monthly declines.
item.contentSnippet:
1) For me the big surprise was seeing California markets now in the decliners list.
At Reventure, we started noticing the slowdown in California last month.
But we weren't expecting LA and San Jose to make the top 10 in terms of monthly declines.

item.title:
Markets with the biggest monthly home price declines in March.
6 markets in Florida. 2 in California.
Austin and Denver around out the list.
If values are declining -0.85% in a month, that annualizes to -10% in a year. Price declines are picking up steam. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
Markets with the biggest monthly home price declines in March.

6 markets in Florida. 2 in California.

Austin and Denver around out the list.

If values are declining -0.85% in a month, that annualizes to -10% in a year. Price declines are picking up steam.

6 markets in Florida. 2 in California.
Austin and Denver around out the list.
If values are declining -0.85% in a month, that annualizes to -10% in a year. Price declines are picking up steam.

item.title:
EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT IN ‘FINAL STAGES’ OF TALKS WITH CHINA TO REMOVE SANCTIONS - SCMP
The European Parliament is in the “final stages” of discussions with Beijing about removing sanctions on its members, smoothing the way for normalised relations with the bloc, according to a spokesperson for the lawmaking body.
“Discussions with the Chinese authorities are continuing and in their final stages,” the spokesperson said. (From Walter Bloomberg)
item.content:
EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT IN ‘FINAL STAGES’ OF TALKS WITH CHINA TO REMOVE SANCTIONS - SCMP

The European Parliament is in the “final stages” of discussions with Beijing about removing sanctions on its members, smoothing the way for normalised relations with the bloc, according to a spokesperson for the lawmaking body.

“Discussions with the Chinese authorities are continuing and in their final stages,” the spokesperson said.
item.contentSnippet:
EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT IN ‘FINAL STAGES’ OF TALKS WITH CHINA TO REMOVE SANCTIONS - SCMP
The European Parliament is in the “final stages” of discussions with Beijing about removing sanctions on its members, smoothing the way for normalised relations with the bloc, according to a spokesperson for the lawmaking body.
“Discussions with the Chinese authorities are continuing and in their final stages,” the spokesperson said.

item.title:
Global trade outlook is deteriorating:
The World Trade Organization expects world merchandise trade to fall -0.2% in 2025, down from +2.7% growth expected at the beginning of the year.
This would follow the +2.9% growth recorded in 2024.
North American trade is set to be hit the hardest, while Asia and Europe will continue to see modest growth.
The WTO also highlights that if the US imposes higher reciprocal tariffs after a 90-day pause, global merchandise trade could drop by -1.5% this year.
For 2026, the WTO forecasts +2.5% growth, down from the previously expected +2.9%.
Global trade is experiencing a historic slowdown. (From TKL)
item.content:
Global trade outlook is deteriorating:

The World Trade Organization expects world merchandise trade to fall -0.2% in 2025, down from +2.7% growth expected at the beginning of the year.

This would follow the +2.9% growth recorded in 2024.

North American trade is set to be hit the hardest, while Asia and Europe will continue to see modest growth.

The WTO also highlights that if the US imposes higher reciprocal tariffs after a 90-day pause, global merchandise trade could drop by -1.5% this year.

For 2026, the WTO forecasts +2.5% growth, down from the previously expected +2.9%.

Global trade is experiencing a historic slowdown.
item.contentSnippet:
Global trade outlook is deteriorating:
The World Trade Organization expects world merchandise trade to fall -0.2% in 2025, down from +2.7% growth expected at the beginning of the year.
This would follow the +2.9% growth recorded in 2024.
North American trade is set to be hit the hardest, while Asia and Europe will continue to see modest growth.
The WTO also highlights that if the US imposes higher reciprocal tariffs after a 90-day pause, global merchandise trade could drop by -1.5% this year.
For 2026, the WTO forecasts +2.5% growth, down from the previously expected +2.9%.
Global trade is experiencing a historic slowdown.

item.title:
OPTIONS TRADERS POSITIONED FOR MORE WILD STOCK SWINGS
Investors are bracing for more stock market volatility ahead. Options traders are betting on a move of 1% or more, higher or lower, in the S&P 500 for every session through at least May 23, according to a Monday note from Citigroup strategists. Those moves are expected to be higher on days of economic importance: Options are pricing in a swing of 1.8% in the benchmark index when the April jobs report is released, and a move of 1.7% the day of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's post-meeting press conference in May. (From Walter Bloomberg)
item.content:
OPTIONS TRADERS POSITIONED FOR MORE WILD STOCK SWINGS

Investors are bracing for more stock market volatility ahead.
Options traders are betting on a move of 1% or more, higher or lower, in the S&P 500 for every session through at least May 23, according to a Monday note from Citigroup strategists.
Those moves are expected to be higher on days of economic importance: Options are pricing in a swing of 1.8% in the benchmark index when the April jobs report is released, and a move of 1.7% the day of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's post-meeting press conference in May.
item.contentSnippet:
OPTIONS TRADERS POSITIONED FOR MORE WILD STOCK SWINGS
Investors are bracing for more stock market volatility ahead. Options traders are betting on a move of 1% or more, higher or lower, in the S&P 500 for every session through at least May 23, according to a Monday note from Citigroup strategists. Those moves are expected to be higher on days of economic importance: Options are pricing in a swing of 1.8% in the benchmark index when the April jobs report is released, and a move of 1.7% the day of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's post-meeting press conference in May.

item.title:
GOLDMAN SACHS LOWERS 1Q GDP ESTIMATE
Goldman Sachs economists now think that the economy grew at a 0.1% annualized pace in the three months through March, down from 0.4% previously. New home sales grew by more than expected last month, but the construction deflator declined by less than Goldman expected, denting the read-through to inflation-adjusted growth. The first official estimate of 1Q GDP from the Commerce Department lands April 30. (From Walter Bloomberg)
item.content:
GOLDMAN SACHS LOWERS 1Q GDP ESTIMATE

Goldman Sachs economists now think that the economy grew at a 0.1% annualized pace in the three months through March, down from 0.4% previously. New home sales grew by more than expected last month, but the construction deflator declined by less than Goldman expected, denting the read-through to inflation-adjusted growth. The first official estimate of 1Q GDP from the Commerce Department lands April 30.
item.contentSnippet:
GOLDMAN SACHS LOWERS 1Q GDP ESTIMATE
Goldman Sachs economists now think that the economy grew at a 0.1% annualized pace in the three months through March, down from 0.4% previously. New home sales grew by more than expected last month, but the construction deflator declined by less than Goldman expected, denting the read-through to inflation-adjusted growth. The first official estimate of 1Q GDP from the Commerce Department lands April 30.

item.title:
RT by @Barchart: American's have $1.77 Trillion in Student Debt, and the Trump Administration is resuming payments and collections. Dave Ramsey calls it a 'parenting crisis' not a debt problem. Is he right? Is poor parenting to blame?

item.title:
And, we are back:
The S&P 500 is now down -100 points from its high of the day as Bessent says Trump has not offered to take down tariffs on China on a unilateral basis.
Bessent has also declined to comment on a WSJ report that claimed tariffs would fall from 145% to 50%-65%.
More conflicting headlines are likely coming next. (From TKL)
item.content:
And, we are back:

The S&P 500 is now down -100 points from its high of the day as Bessent says Trump has not offered to take down tariffs on China on a unilateral basis.

Bessent has also declined to comment on a WSJ report that claimed tariffs would fall from 145% to 50%-65%.

More conflicting headlines are likely coming next.
item.contentSnippet:
And, we are back:
The S&P 500 is now down -100 points from its high of the day as Bessent says Trump has not offered to take down tariffs on China on a unilateral basis.
Bessent has also declined to comment on a WSJ report that claimed tariffs would fall from 145% to 50%-65%.
More conflicting headlines are likely coming next.

item.title: Thanks Bessent 🤦‍♂️🤦‍♂️ (From Barchart)
item.content: Thanks Bessent 🤦‍♂️🤦‍♂️
item.contentSnippet: Thanks Bessent 🤦‍♂️🤦‍♂️

item.title:
Over the last 24 hours:
1. Trump says tariffs on China won’t be as high as 145% and “will come down substantially"
2. Bessent says "de-escalation with China" is coming
3. WSJ reports that tariffs on China are set to drop to 50%-65%
4. Bessent says America "first does not mean America alone"
5. Bessent declines to comment on WSJ report in point #3
6. Bessent clarifies Trump is not offering a unilateral decrease in tariffs on China
7. Bessent says US-China trade deal will take 2 to 3 years
The market's rollercoaster ride continues. (From TKL)
item.content:
Over the last 24 hours:

1. Trump says tariffs on China won’t be as high as 145% and “will come down substantially"

2. Bessent says "de-escalation with China" is coming

3. WSJ reports that tariffs on China are set to drop to 50%-65%

4. Bessent says America "first does not mean America alone"

5. Bessent declines to comment on WSJ report in point #3

6. Bessent clarifies Trump is not offering a unilateral decrease in tariffs on China

7. Bessent says US-China trade deal will take 2 to 3 years

The market's rollercoaster ride continues.
item.contentSnippet:
Over the last 24 hours:
1. Trump says tariffs on China won’t be as high as 145% and “will come down substantially"
2. Bessent says "de-escalation with China" is coming
3. WSJ reports that tariffs on China are set to drop to 50%-65%
4. Bessent says America "first does not mean America alone"
5. Bessent declines to comment on WSJ report in point #3
6. Bessent clarifies Trump is not offering a unilateral decrease in tariffs on China
7. Bessent says US-China trade deal will take 2 to 3 years
The market's rollercoaster ride continues.

item.title:
Here we go again:
Bessent now saying that President Trump has not offered to take down US tariffs on China on a unilateral basis.
The ball is in China's court and Bessent just said it will take 2-3 years to reach a deal.
How does China respond now? (From TKL)
item.content:
Here we go again:

Bessent now saying that President Trump has not offered to take down US tariffs on China on a unilateral basis.

The ball is in China's court and Bessent just said it will take 2-3 years to reach a deal.

How does China respond now?
item.contentSnippet:
Here we go again:
Bessent now saying that President Trump has not offered to take down US tariffs on China on a unilateral basis.
The ball is in China's court and Bessent just said it will take 2-3 years to reach a deal.
How does China respond now?

item.title:
BREAKING: US Treasury Secretary Bessent says a trade deal with China may take 2-3 years to reach, declines to comment on WSJ report.
The S&P 500 is paring gains, now down 60 points from its high of the day. (From TKL)
item.content:
BREAKING: US Treasury Secretary Bessent says a trade deal with China may take 2-3 years to reach, declines to comment on WSJ report.

The S&P 500 is paring gains, now down 60 points from its high of the day.
item.contentSnippet:
BREAKING: US Treasury Secretary Bessent says a trade deal with China may take 2-3 years to reach, declines to comment on WSJ report.
The S&P 500 is paring gains, now down 60 points from its high of the day.

item.title: R to @nickgerli1: 7) Access overvaluation/undervaluation data for your housing market at http://www.reventure.app under a premium plan. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content: 7) Access overvaluation/undervaluation data for your housing market at reventure.app under a premium plan.
item.contentSnippet: 7) Access overvaluation/undervaluation data for your housing market at reventure.app under a premium plan.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 6) To be clear: all these housing markets still have some issues. Particularly, outbound migration. They all lost people during pandemic, and still might be losing some people today.
But in terms of fundamentals (home prices to income, and to rent) they are well-priced. And historically affordable.
Indicating we could be seeing a renaissance for the legacy big city housing markets the next 5 years. Especially if return to office mandates keep happening. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
6) To be clear: all these housing markets still have some issues. Particularly, outbound migration. They all lost people during pandemic, and still might be losing some people today.

But in terms of fundamentals (home prices to income, and to rent) they are well-priced. And historically affordable.

Indicating we could be seeing a renaissance for the legacy big city housing markets the next 5 years. Especially if return to office mandates keep happening.
item.contentSnippet:
6) To be clear: all these housing markets still have some issues. Particularly, outbound migration. They all lost people during pandemic, and still might be losing some people today.
But in terms of fundamentals (home prices to income, and to rent) they are well-priced. And historically affordable.
Indicating we could be seeing a renaissance for the legacy big city housing markets the next 5 years. Especially if return to office mandates keep happening.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 5) I think this next one is my favorite, though. Cook County in Chicago.
In the last bubble, prices were trading at 5.2x incomes in Chicago.
Then there was a correction. And since then, values have kept pace with incomes, and today's 3.7x multiple is one of the cheapest in the country for a major city. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
5) I think this next one is my favorite, though. Cook County in Chicago.

In the last bubble, prices were trading at 5.2x incomes in Chicago.

Then there was a correction. And since then, values have kept pace with incomes, and today's 3.7x multiple is one of the cheapest in the country for a major city.
item.contentSnippet:
5) I think this next one is my favorite, though. Cook County in Chicago.
In the last bubble, prices were trading at 5.2x incomes in Chicago.
Then there was a correction. And since then, values have kept pace with incomes, and today's 3.7x multiple is one of the cheapest in the country for a major city.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 4) Here's another example: Suffolk County, MA (Boston).
The Home/Value income ratio in Boston is 7.6x. today. Which is a hair below it's long-term 20-year average.
Inidcating that the growth in incomes has kept up with the growth in prices (there was actually a slight correction in prices in Boston the last 2 years). (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
4) Here's another example: Suffolk County, MA (Boston).

The Home/Value income ratio in Boston is 7.6x. today. Which is a hair below it's long-term 20-year average.

Inidcating that the growth in incomes has kept up with the growth in prices (there was actually a slight correction in prices in Boston the last 2 years).
item.contentSnippet:
4) Here's another example: Suffolk County, MA (Boston).
The Home/Value income ratio in Boston is 7.6x. today. Which is a hair below it's long-term 20-year average.
Inidcating that the growth in incomes has kept up with the growth in prices (there was actually a slight correction in prices in Boston the last 2 years).

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 3) To be clear: Manhattan is still expensive. In fact, it's one of the 5 most expensive housing markets in America.
However, it is cheap today compared to its historical norms. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
3) To be clear: Manhattan is still expensive. In fact, it's one of the 5 most expensive housing markets in America.

However, it is cheap today compared to its historical norms.
item.contentSnippet:
3) To be clear: Manhattan is still expensive. In fact, it's one of the 5 most expensive housing markets in America.
However, it is cheap today compared to its historical norms.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 2) The average 20-year home price/income ratio in Manhattan is 14.4.
Meaning homes/condos typically trade for 14x median income.
Yet today, they're trading for 10.8x median income.
The lowest multiple in decades. Indicating that the market is undervalued. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
2) The average 20-year home price/income ratio in Manhattan is 14.4.

Meaning homes/condos typically trade for 14x median income.

Yet today, they're trading for 10.8x median income.

The lowest multiple in decades. Indicating that the market is undervalued.
item.contentSnippet:
2) The average 20-year home price/income ratio in Manhattan is 14.4.
Meaning homes/condos typically trade for 14x median income.
Yet today, they're trading for 10.8x median income.
The lowest multiple in decades. Indicating that the market is undervalued.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 1) DC might be an exception given how the federal workforce is getting cut.
But in general, home values in these areas are trading at very reasonable levels compared to incomes.
For instance, take a look at Manhattan. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
1) DC might be an exception given how the federal workforce is getting cut.

But in general, home values in these areas are trading at very reasonable levels compared to incomes.

For instance, take a look at Manhattan.
item.contentSnippet:
1) DC might be an exception given how the federal workforce is getting cut.
But in general, home values in these areas are trading at very reasonable levels compared to incomes.
For instance, take a look at Manhattan.

item.title:
Here are the counties in America that are "undervalued" in terms of home prices to income.
Manhattan - 25% undervalued Bronx - 22% DC - 18% New Orelans - 11% San Francisco- 11% Queens - 5% Brooklyn - 4% Chicago - 3% Boston - 2%
All legacy, big city housing markets for most part. They struggled during pandemic and lost people. But now they could be in for a turn-around.
Real estate is the cheapest it's been in these areas in decades. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
Here are the counties in America that are "undervalued" in terms of home prices to income.

Manhattan - 25% undervalued
Bronx - 22%
DC - 18%
New Orelans - 11%
San Francisco- 11%
Queens - 5%
Brooklyn - 4%
Chicago - 3%
Boston - 2%

All legacy, big city housing markets for most part. They struggled during pandemic and lost people. But now they could be in for a turn-around.

Real estate is the cheapest it's been in these areas in decades.
item.contentSnippet:
Here are the counties in America that are "undervalued" in terms of home prices to income.
Manhattan - 25% undervalued Bronx - 22% DC - 18% New Orelans - 11% San Francisco- 11% Queens - 5% Brooklyn - 4% Chicago - 3% Boston - 2%
All legacy, big city housing markets for most part. They struggled during pandemic and lost people. But now they could be in for a turn-around.
Real estate is the cheapest it's been in these areas in decades.

• Revenue -9% Y/Y to $19.3B ($2.1B miss). • Gross margin 16% (-1pp Y/Y). • Operating margin 2% (-3pp Y/Y). • Capex -46% Y/Y to $1.5B. • Free cash flow $0.6B. • Non-GAAP EPS $0.27 ($0.15 miss). (From App Economy Insights)
item.content:

• Revenue -9% Y/Y to $19.3B ($2.1B miss).
• Gross margin 16% (-1pp Y/Y).
• Operating margin 2% (-3pp Y/Y).
• Capex -46% Y/Y to $1.5B.
• Free cash flow $0.6B.
• Non-GAAP EPS $0.27 ($0.15 miss).

item.content:
7) Access the data for Manhattan real estate at reventure.app, including our overvaluation rates and price forecasts by ZIP code.

You can access both under a premium plan.
item.contentSnippet:
7) Access the data for Manhattan real estate at reventure.app, including our overvaluation rates and price forecasts by ZIP code.
You can access both under a premium plan.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 6) No one else in the housing market is really talking about Manhattan.
But I think it could be poised for a big rebound soon.
The market is the cheapest it's been in decades relative to income and rent.
Suggesting a turnaround could be in the offering. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)

Creating an undervalued market. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)

item.title:
RT by @SchwabResearch: Today on The Big Picture on Market On Close:
— @LizAnnSonders says that "any move by the Fed to preemptively start easing policy aggressively ... might not have the intended effect of boosting growth or boosting confidence."
— Cooper Howard tells @Cline_Woods that "the market is concerned about the independence of the Fed."
— Plus, tracking the likelihood of a recession. (From SchwabR)
item.content:
Today on The Big Picture on Market On Close:

— @LizAnnSonders says that "any move by the Fed to preemptively start easing policy aggressively ... might not have the intended effect of boosting growth or boosting confidence."

— Cooper Howard tells @Cline_Woods that "the market is concerned about the independence of the Fed."

— Plus, tracking the likelihood of a recession.
